comments.body:
Given that we're already in "Attr land", would it be enough to call this:
```suggestion
   const RAttrLine &Line() const { return fAttrLine; }
```
?
What's the relationship between this and the label-axes, which have their own array of bin labels?
This flag disable any kind of labels drawing
Sorry, that one should have been obvious to me :-/

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +48,52 @@   RAttrValue<int> fTicksWidth{this, "ticks_width", 1};                  ///<! ticks width
   RAttrValue<bool> fHideLabels{this, "hidelabels", false};              ///<! disable labels drawing
   RAttrText fAttrLabels{this, "labels"};                                ///<! text attributes for labels
   RAttrValue<RPadLength> fLabelsOffset{this, "labels_offset", {}};      ///<! axis labels offset - relative
   RAttrValue<bool> fLabelsCenter{this, "labels_center", false};         ///<! center labels

comments.body: Please add a `public:` somewhere, even if that's part of `R__ATTR_CLASS_DERIVED`.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +53,57 @@public:

   RAttrValue<std::string> value{this, "value", ""};            ///<! axis title value
   RAttrValue<std::string> position{this, "position", "right"}; ///<! axis title position - left, right, center
   RAttrValue<RPadLength> offset{this, "offset", {}};           ///<! axis title offset - relative to "default" position

comments.body: This doesn't seem to be just attributes: it contains the title itself, no? Would `RAxisTitle` be more appropriate?
It is all kind of axis title attributes - font, position, color, size. But also title.
Why do these two have so different acceptance / precision (`1E-6` vs `0.1`)?
One should be able to specify `e` as `2.7` without need to provide more precise value.

I find it surprising that title attributes and title string are in the same `RAttrAxis` class (esp with it being named "Attr"). I might get used to it. But I also find it inconsistent that I can do `attrAxis.log = 2` but not `attrAxis.title = "Title"`.

We discussed that for these special member names we'd spell usage as
```suggestion
   RAttrAxisTitle& operator=(const std::string &_title) { this->value = _title; return *this; }
```
to clarify that it's a member access, not access to a local variable. If you find this too much clutter for these simple cases then that's fine; I will call out cases below where this pattern is certainly more useful.
